openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Peru is classified by the World Bank as an emerging, mixed economy with an upper middle income status, characterized by a high level of foreign trade.
• Peru ranks as the forty-seventh largest economy globally by total GDP and currently exhibits a high human development index.
• In 2012, Peru was among the world’s fastest-growing economies, achieving a GDP growth rate of 6.3%.
• The economy was projected to grow by 9.3% in 2021, reflecting a rebound from the COVID-19 pandemic’s economic impact.
• Peru has established multiple free trade agreements with key partners, including the China–Peru Free Trade Agreement signed on 28 April 2009, which made China its largest trading partner.
• Additional free trade agreements were signed with the United States in 2006, Japan in 2011, and the European Union in 2012.
• Economic activities such as trade and industry are concentrated in Lima, while agricultural exports have driven regional development across Peru.
• Peru’s economy heavily depends on commodity exports, rendering it vulnerable to international market price volatility.
• Historically, the Peruvian government has maintained limited involvement in the public sector, often relying on commodity booms for economic growth.
• Commodity extraction has caused internal conflicts due to environmental degradation and social impacts.

• After independence from the Spanish Empire, economic power was centralized in coastal regions under a system known as _centralismo_, while rural provinces remained under serfdom-like control by _hacienda_ landowners.

• This socio-economic model persisted until 1968, when General Juan Velasco Alvarado’s dictatorship increased social spending and diminished landowners’ power, creating a power vacuum in the 1970s that facilitated the rise of the communist guerrilla group Shining Path.
• During the 1980s, Peru experienced economic difficulties due to the early 1980s recession and internal conflict, known as the Lost Decade.
• The government of Alan García implemented price controls that led to hyperinflation.
• In response, the Peruvian armed forces developed Plan Verde, aiming to establish a neoliberal, open market economy.
• Plan Verde was reportedly implemented during Alberto Fujimori’s government, influenced by economist Hernando de Soto, in a period called "Fujishock."
• Fujishock involved discontinuing price controls, privatizing state-run organizations, and promoting foreign investment through deregulation.
• These economic reforms under Fujimori’s administration achieved macroeconomic stability in Peru.
• Economic development accelerated following the 2000s commodities boom, with improvements in government finances, poverty reduction, and social sector progress.
• Peru has more recently embraced the Lima Consensus, an economic ideology emphasizing neoliberalism, deregulation, and free market policies, which has attracted foreign portfolio investment.
• Inflation in Peru was the lowest in Latin America at 1.8% in 2012, with a recent annual rate of 1.9% in 2020.
• Statistical poverty rates declined significantly from nearly 60% in 2004 to 20.5% in 2018.

• Peru’s economic performance remains closely tied to exports, which generate hard currency essential for financing imports and external debt payments, though economic diversification has increased in recent decades.
• Peru’s main exports include copper, gold, zinc, textiles, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, manufactured goods, machinery, services, and fish meal.
• The country’s major trade partners are the United States, China, Brazil, the European Union, and Chile.
• Despite substantial export revenues, Peru has struggled to achieve self-sustained economic growth and a more equitable income distribution.
• The services sector accounts for 59.9% of Peru’s gross domestic product, followed by industry at 32.7%, and agriculture at 7.6%.
• Recent economic growth has been driven by macroeconomic stability, improved terms of trade, and increased investment and consumption.
• The Tahuantinsuyo, also known as the Realm of the Four Parts, was the largest civilization to emerge from the highlands of Peru in the early 13th century and is popularly known as the Inca Empire.
• The Spanish conquest culminated in 1572 with the fall of the last Inca stronghold, marking the end of the Inca Empire.
• The Inca Empire utilized a system of central planning to manage its economy and resources efficiently.
• Spanish chronicler Pedro Cieza de León described the Inca tax system as highly effective, noting that the people prospered under it and did not feel burdened by the taxes.

• According to Cieza de León, the Inca tax system was so orderly that natives consistently paid their assessed tributes, and tax collectors never took more than what was owed, not even a single grain of corn in excess.
• Inca officials traveled to cities and provinces equipped with quipus, which were knotted strings used to store and transmit data related to tax assessments and contributions.
• Inca territories contributed various resources to the empire, including labor (known as mit'a), textiles, food, weapons, and construction materials.
• The mit'a labor system required provinces to provide men who were married, ensuring that their wives could maintain household and community life during their absence.
• The Inca labor system was designed to prevent overwork; individuals who became ill during their service were returned to their home provinces and replaced by others.
• The Inca calendar included many days dedicated to recreation and feasts, reflecting a balance between labor obligations and social or religious activities.
• The economy of the Viceroyalty of Peru was predominantly reliant on the export of silver, which was a major economic driver during the colonial period.

• Large quantities of silver exported from the Viceroyalty of Peru and Mexico had a significant impact on Europe’s economy, with some scholars attributing these exports to the onset of the European price revolution.

• Silver mining operations in the Viceroyalty utilized a combination of labor systems, including contract laborers, free wage laborers, and the _encomienda_ system, which involved forced indigenous labor akin to slavery.
• The _encomienda_ system has been characterized by historians as constituting genocide due to its devastating effects on the indigenous population.

• Spanish chronicler Cieza de León documented the severe demographic decline caused by Spanish exploitation, stating that the indigenous population had diminished drastically and faced potential complete extinction due to Spanish greed and disorder.
• The presence of Afro-Peruvians in colonial Peru resulted from the transatlantic slave trade and the institution of slavery in Spanish America.
• Silver production in the Viceroyalty of Peru reached its peak around the year 1610, marking the height of colonial mining output.
• In 1802, Prussian explorer Alexander von Humboldt discovered guano deposits in Callao, Peru, initiating scientific research into its use as a fertilizer.
• Humboldt’s findings on guano were disseminated throughout Europe, influencing agricultural practices and fertilizer research internationally.
• Peru gained independence from Spain on 28 July 1821, but subsequently faced significant financial difficulties.
• The Peruvian economy was further weakened by the collapse of its silver mines, a traditional source of wealth.
• Starting in the 1840s, the guano trade with Europe became a major economic driver, attracting substantial European investments and capital into Peru.

• In 1840, Francisco Quirós y Ampudia, a Peruvian politician and entrepreneur, formalized the commercialization of guano exports through an agreement involving French businessmen and the Peruvian government.
• This agreement abolished all existing private claims to Peruvian guano, effectively nationalizing the resource under state control.
• Guano quickly became Peru’s largest source of government revenue, underpinning the national economy during this period.
• Despite concerns about the near exhaustion of guano reserves, Peru reached its highest recorded guano export volume in 1870, exporting over 700,000 tonnes (770,000 short tons).
• The Chincha Islands were a major source of guano during this era, playing a critical role in Peru’s export economy.
• Chile experienced severe economic devastation during the Long Depression of the 1870s, prompting the country to seek alternatives to its traditional exports of silver, copper, and wheat.
• Historians largely agree that Chile's economic difficulties and the potential wealth from nitrate deposits were primary motivations for the Chilean elite to engage in war against Peru and Bolivia.
• The Chilean government's expansionist foreign policy aimed at controlling the mineral-rich Atacama region was a significant factor leading to the War of the Pacific.
• Chile emerged victorious in the War of the Pacific, which officially ended with the signing of the Treaty of Ancón in 1884.

• As a result of the treaty, Chile acquired half of Peru's guano income starting in the 1880s, along with control over Peru’s guano islands, which contained some of the world’s most valuable nitrogen resources.
• The acquisition of these territories and resources caused Chile’s national treasury to increase by 900% between 1879 and 1902.
• In contrast, Peru’s economy, heavily dependent on commodity exports, suffered bankruptcy following the war, continuing a historical pattern of economic vulnerability.
• To address its financial crisis, Peru approved the Grace Contract, which transferred ownership of the country’s railroads to holders of sovereign debt.
• Following the Grace Contract, the Peruvian government refrained from issuing new sovereign debt until the year 1906.
• Into the twentieth century, the Anglo-Peruvian Amazon Rubber Co, based in Iquitos, began marketing rubber on the international market.
• The rubber boom integrated regions of Amazonia into the global economy, significantly increasing international trade in rubber.
• The Government of Peru ceded the Amazon territories north of Loreto to the Anglo-Peruvian Amazon Rubber Co after the company's founder, Julio César Arana, purchased the land.
• During the rubber boom, the Anglo-Peruvian Amazon Rubber Co committed the Putumayo Genocide against indigenous populations.
• Between 40,000 and 250,000 indigenous peoples were killed as a result of the Putumayo Genocide.
• Many indigenous victims were forced into labor camps under brutal conditions during the rubber boom.
• Ninety percent of the affected Amazonian indigenous populations were annihilated due to the violence and exploitation perpetrated by the Anglo-Peruvian Amazon Rubber Co.

sections.section_name: World War I and II eras
openai_summarised_points: • In the early 1910s, Peru experienced economic growth driven by mining and crop production, alongside the development of a working class.
• The outbreak of World War I caused turbulence in international markets, leading Peru into a recession and a series of coups throughout the mid to late 1910s.
• Augusto B. Leguía, a member of Peru's oligarchy, seized power through a coup and assumed dictatorial powers, drafting a new constitution which he frequently disregarded in practice.
• Víctor Raúl Haya de la Torre founded the American Popular Revolutionary Alliance (APRA), advocating for reforms; however, Leguía quickly banned the party.
• Leguía increased government spending to modernize Peru, which raised the national debt significantly.
• The onset of the Great Depression in 1929 exacerbated economic difficulties, leading to Leguía’s overthrow in 1930 by Luis Miguel Sánchez Cerro.
• President Sánchez announced a debt moratorium on US$180 million, resulting in Peru being banned from United States markets.
• Sánchez’s government continued repression of APRA, culminating in the assassination of Sánchez by an Aprista party member.

• Óscar R. Benavides was appointed by the constituent assembly to complete Sánchez’s term and intensified persecution of left-wing groups, which increased support for the Peruvian Communist Party (PCP) among indigenous and labor groups.
• As Peru’s economy grew, Manuel Prado Ugarteche, a banker from Lima, was elected president in the 1939 Peruvian general election.
• President Prado adopted a more conciliatory approach toward APRA, while Aprista leader Haya de la Torre promoted moderate policies and support for foreign markets.
• APRA was legalized in 1945, and José Luis Bustamante y Rivero was elected president the same year, appointing an Aprista politician as Minister of the Economy.
• Under Bustamante’s administration, economic interventionism increased significantly, including the implementation of price controls and foreign exchange controls.
• Despite interventionist policies, the economy slowed and inflation increased during Bustamante’s presidency.
• Over the two decades following 1948, Peru was predominantly controlled by military juntas, marking a period of military governance in the country’s political landscape.
• On 29 October 1948, General Manuel A. Odría led a successful military coup that ousted President Bustamante and assumed the presidency, ruling until 1956.
• During Odría’s administration, Peru experienced economic growth driven by a commodity boom; however, government investments were largely concentrated in coastal cities.
• Despite economic growth, significant unrest and poverty persisted in the interior and Andean regions, which remained marginalized and impoverished under Odría’s rule.

• Víctor Raúl Haya de la Torre, leader of the American Popular Revolutionary Alliance (APRA) party, which had shifted further to right-wing politics during this period, won the 1962 general election against Fernando Belaúnde, founder of the right-wing Popular Action party.
• Haya de la Torre was prevented from assuming office due to a military coup that opposed APRA’s political influence, leading to a brief period of military government.

• Fernando Belaúnde subsequently won the 1963 general election and became president, initiating modest improvements including increased industrialization and the construction of highways into the Andes region.

• Belaúnde promoted a political and economic doctrine known as "The Conquest of Peru by Peruvians," aimed at exploiting natural resources in the Amazon and other peripheral areas through internal conquest and development.

• In 1964, under Belaúnde’s administration, the Matsé genocide occurred when the government targeted the Matsés indigenous group following the killing of two loggers; Peruvian armed forces, supported by American fighter planes, used napalm against the indigenous people armed only with bows and arrows, resulting in the deaths of hundreds.

• Belaúnde’s economic policies, heavily reliant on resource exports such as the fishing industry, led to increased inflation and a growing fiscal deficit, causing disapproval and unrest among rural and peasant populations.
• The growing economic and social conflicts during Belaúnde’s presidency culminated in the 1968 Peruvian coup d’état, when General Juan Velasco Alvarado overthrew Belaúnde’s government.

sections.section_name: Revolutionary Government of the Armed Forces
openai_summarised_points: • General Juan Velasco Alvarado established the Revolutionary Government of the Armed Forces in Peru, adopting a state capitalism economic policy during a period of economic expansion.
• The Velasco government immediately implemented land reform initiatives, launching one of the most ambitious land tenure projects in Latin American history.

• These land reform projects dismantled the traditional hacienda system, which resembled a form of serfdom imposed by landowners on peasants, and replaced it with agricultural cooperatives known as Agricultural Social-Interest Societies (SAIS).

• Velasco’s government pursued a structural economic approach by investing heavily in infrastructure development and initiating a widespread nationalization campaign targeting key sectors of economic production, education, and the media.
• A fixed exchange rate system was adopted under Velasco’s administration, which coincided with a dramatic increase in Peru’s national debt.
• The combination of rising debt, inflation, and the global 1973 oil crisis precipitated a severe economic crisis during Velasco’s tenure.
• General Francisco Morales-Bermúdez led a coup known as the Tacnazo, overthrowing Velasco and assuming leadership of the government.

• Morales-Bermúdez nominally headed the Second Revolutionary Government of the Armed Forces, which implemented austerity measures and dismantled the state capitalist economic systems established by Velasco.
• The Morales-Bermúdez government initiated monetary adjustments and commenced negotiations concerning Peru’s foreign debt obligations.
• Despite these efforts, the government was plagued by corruption scandals and widespread public protests.
• Facing mounting pressure, the military government under Morales-Bermúdez agreed to transition Peru back to a democratic political system.
• In 1980, after twelve years of military rule in Peru, Fernando Belaúnde Terry was elected president for a second term.
• On the day of the 1980 election, the Shining Path initiated its armed struggle in Chuschi by burning ballots, marking the beginning of Peru's internal conflict.
• Belaúnde's administration implemented a floating exchange rate and pursued populist policies, primarily relying on key exports to drive the economy.
• His government continued to reverse the policies of former leader Juan Velasco Alvarado and introduced some economic liberalization measures.

• Despite these efforts, Belaúnde's government failed to develop an effective monetary policy, mismanaged state-run enterprises, and faced a growing external debt, leaving Peru economically vulnerable.
• In the 1985 general election, Alan García was elected president, becoming the first Aprista leader in over sixty years.

• García’s administration adopted a neo-structuralist economic policy, which involved government funding of the private sector to boost economic performance, increased welfare spending, and the institution of price controls.
• These policies resulted in temporary economic growth but caused a dramatic increase in Peru’s national debt.
• By 1989, inflation in Peru reached nearly 3,000 percent, and it escalated further to 7,000 percent in 1990.
• During the last three years of García’s presidency, Peru experienced a GDP contraction of 24 percent.
• The worsening economic crisis coincided with the Shining Path terrorist group expanding its territorial control amid armed conflict with the government.
• According to scholars Gutiérrez Sanín and Schönwälder, the combination of economic turmoil and insurgency made the idea of a strong, authoritarian leader more appealing to the Peruvian populace.
• The Peruvian armed forces grew increasingly frustrated with García’s inability to manage the country’s crises and began planning to overthrow his government.

• Sociologist and political analyst Fernando Rospigliosi noted that Peru’s business elites maintained connections with the military planners, likely providing economic ideas favoring a liberal economic program and the establishment of an authoritarian government to restore order.
• At the end of García’s presidency, the military drafted Plan Verde, which aimed to establish a civilian-military government implementing neoliberal economic policies.
• During the 1990 presidential campaign, Alberto Fujimori expressed opposition to the neoliberal economic policies proposed by his opponent, Mario Vargas Llosa.
• According to the Peruvian magazine _Oiga_, after Fujimori's election victory, the Peruvian armed forces were uncertain about his commitment to fulfilling their objectives as outlined in Plan Verde.
• It was reported that the armed forces held a negotiation meeting with Fujimori to ensure his adherence to their strategic direction as specified in Plan Verde.

• Upon assuming office on 28 July 1990, Fujimori abandoned the economic platform he had promoted during his campaign and instead implemented more aggressive neoliberal policies than those advocated by Vargas Llosa.
• Fujimori adopted many of the economic and political policies outlined in Plan Verde during his presidency.
• Alberto Fujimori served as President of Peru from 28 July 1990 until his resignation on 17 November 2000.
• Fujimori is widely credited with defeating the Shining Path terrorist group, a significant insurgent threat in Peru during his tenure.
• He is also recognized for restoring macroeconomic stability to Peru following a period of economic crisis.

• Fujimori’s economic policies were largely influenced by Peruvian economist Hernando de Soto, who recommended loosening economic regulations, implementing austerity measures, and adopting neoliberal economic reforms.
• The economic guidelines advised by Hernando de Soto were incorporated into the Fujimori administration’s policies and were institutionalized in the 1993 Constitution of Peru.
• Despite improvements in Peru’s overall economic statistics from 1990 to 2020, the wealth generated during this period was unevenly distributed across the country.
• Significant disparities in living standards persisted between the more developed capital city of Lima and other coastal regions compared to the impoverished rural provinces.
• The section on Peru bonds lists government bond maturities available in the 21st century, specifically including 30-year, 20-year, 15-year, 10-year, 5-year, and 2-year bonds.
• These bonds represent various fixed-income securities issued by the Peruvian government to finance public spending and manage national debt across different time horizons.
• The availability of bonds with maturities ranging from 2 years to 30 years indicates Peru’s engagement in long-term and short-term debt instruments to attract diverse investors.
• The issuance of these bonds reflects Peru’s efforts to maintain fiscal stability and support economic growth through capital market development in the 21st century.

• The Lima Consensus was initially established by the Fujimori administration in Peru, emphasizing deregulation and privatization to create a neoliberal economy while limiting government involvement in the public sector.

• During the 2000s, as the Washington Consensus declined in popularity, the Lima Consensus became more distinctly defined in Peru, coinciding with economic improvements driven by the commodities boom of that decade.

• Unlike many Latin American governments that increased investments in social programs for education, healthcare, and poverty alleviation in the early 21st century, Peru under the Lima Consensus opted to reduce social program expenditures.
• President Alejandro Toledo promoted the decentralization of Peru’s government as part of the Consensus framework.
• Former social democrat Alan García further intensified the implementation of the Lima Consensus by adopting policies reminiscent of Augusto Pinochet’s neoliberal approach.

• Keiko Fujimori, daughter of former President Alberto Fujimori, has been a prominent advocate of the Lima Consensus, leveraging support from neoliberal economist Hernando de Soto during her electoral campaigns.

• The Consensus’s emphasis on minimal state intervention has led to a weakened government characterized by poor performance in delivering essential services such as education, justice, and security to many Peruvians.

• Concurrently, corruption, crime, crony capitalism, and economic inequality have increased, exacerbated by the frequent revolving door of political officials moving between business and government roles without adequate oversight.

• After the 2021 Peruvian general election, which resulted in the victory of leftist candidate Pedro Castillo, Fitch Solutions issued a warning that his presidency posed "substantial risks to the 'Lima Consensus'," the investor-friendly economic policy framework that had been dominant in Peru for the previous 20 years.
• Peru's diverse climates and geographical zones contribute to its status as a significant agricultural nation with a highly diversified agricultural sector.

• Peruvian agricultural exports are well-regarded internationally and include key products such as artichokes, grapes, avocados, mangoes, peppers, sugarcane, organic coffee, and premium-quality cotton.
• Peru ranks among the top global producers in several crops: it is one of the five largest producers worldwide of avocado, blueberry, artichoke, and asparagus.
• The country is also among the ten largest producers globally of coffee and cocoa.
• Peru ranks within the top fifteen producers worldwide for potato and pineapple.
• Additionally, Peru has substantial production levels of grape, sugarcane, rice, banana, maize, and cassava, reflecting its agricultural diversification.

• In 2018, Peru's agricultural production volumes included: 10.3 million tons of sugarcane, 5.1 million tons of potato, 3.5 million tons of rice, 2.2 million tons of banana, 1.5 million tons of maize, and 1.2 million tons of cassava.

• Other significant 2018 production figures were 921 thousand tons of palm oil, 645 thousand tons of grape, 548 thousand tons of pineapple, 504 thousand tons of avocado, and 481 thousand tons of tangerine.

• Further 2018 outputs included 502 thousand tons of orange, 369 thousand tons of coffee, 383 thousand tons of mango, 360 thousand tons of asparagus, 270 thousand tons of lemon, and 252 thousand tons of tomato.

• Additional production data for 2018 comprised 207 thousand tons of barley, 195 thousand tons of wheat, 188 thousand tons of olives, 187 thousand tons of carrots, 175 thousand tons each of papaya and pepper, 154 thousand tons of artichoke, 140 thousand tons of apple, and 134 thousand tons of cocoa.
• Peru also produces smaller quantities of various other agricultural products, contributing to the overall diversity of its agricultural sector.
• The Camisea Gas Project in La Convención Province, Cuzco, includes a natural gas separation plant integral to Peru's extraction sector.
• Ferrol Bay near Chimbote hosts a significant fishing fleet; in the mid-20th century, Chimbote's port was the largest fishing production port globally.
• Peru is an international leader in fishing, accounting for nearly 10 percent of the world's total fish catch.
• Mining constitutes a major pillar of the Peruvian economy, with Peru ranking as the 2nd largest global producer of copper and silver in 2019.
• In 2019, Peru was the 8th largest world producer of gold, reflecting its continued importance in precious metal extraction.
• Peru ranked as the 3rd largest world producer of lead in 2019, demonstrating its significant role in base metal mining.
• The country was the 2nd largest world producer of zinc in 2019, underscoring its prominence in zinc extraction.
• In 2019, Peru was the 4th largest world producer of tin, contributing substantially to the global tin supply.
• Peru was the 5th largest world producer of boron in 2019, highlighting its importance in this mineral market.
• The country ranked as the 4th largest world producer of molybdenum in 2019, indicating its diverse mining sector.
• Historically, Peru was once the world's largest producer of silver and was among the top five global gold producers, reflecting its longstanding mining heritage.

• Illegal mining in Peru remains a significant issue, causing environmental damage such as deforestation and pollution, as well as social problems including prostitution, poor working conditions, and criminal activity.
• Peru has developed a medium-sized manufacturing sector that currently represents 23 percent of the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• The manufacturing sector in Peru is closely linked to key industries such as mining, fishing, agriculture, construction, and textiles.
• The primary focus of Peru’s manufacturing sector is on processing activities aimed at achieving a value-added advantage.

• Among the various manufacturing subsectors, the most promising areas include textiles, metal mechanics, the food industry, the agricultural industry, general manufactures, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, machinery, and services.
• Tourism has emerged as a new growth industry in Peru since the early 1990s, marking a significant shift in the country’s economic focus within the services sector.
• Both the Peruvian government and the private sector have invested substantial efforts and resources to promote and enhance the country’s tourist destinations.
• These promotional activities target both domestic tourists (Peruvians) and international visitors, aiming to increase tourism inflows and economic benefits.
• Peru's natural resources encompass a diverse range of minerals and materials, including copper, silver, gold, timber, fish, iron ore, coal, phosphate, potash, and natural gas.

sections.section_name: Foreign trade and balance of payments
openai_summarised_points: • In 2001, Peru's current account deficit decreased to approximately 2.2% of GDP, equivalent to US$1.17 billion, down from 3.1% in 2000, while the trade balance recorded a small deficit.
• Exports in 2001 slightly declined to US$7.11 billion, whereas imports fell by 2.1% to US$7.20 billion.
• Fisheries exports, which had been severely affected by the El Niño phenomenon in 1998, showed recovery by 2001.
• Minerals and metals exports experienced significant growth in 2001 and 2002, largely due to the commencement of operations at the Antamina copper-zinc mine.
• By mid-2002, most sectors of the Peruvian economy were demonstrating positive growth trends.
• Foreign direct investment (FDI) not related to privatization sharply declined in 2000, 2001, and the first half of 2002 after several years of substantial growth.

• Net international reserves increased steadily, standing at US$9.16 billion at the end of May 2002, up from US$8.6 billion in 2001; reserves further rose to US$17 billion by the end of 2006, exceeded US$20 billion in 2007, and surpassed US$35 billion by May 2008.
• Peru has entered into multiple free trade agreements, including the 2007 United States-Peru Trade Promotion Agreement, as well as agreements with Chile, Canada, Singapore, Thailand, and China.
• Under President Alan García’s administration, Peru secured a bilateral trade agreement with the United States in 2010 aimed at enhancing export capacity.
• Following the U.S.-Peru trade agreement, Peru reached a peak in exports in August 2011, exceeding US$4,700 million (4.7 billion).
• The Port of Callao serves as Peru's primary gateway for both exports and imports, playing a crucial role in the country's foreign trade.
• The Peruvian government actively promotes the attraction of foreign and domestic investment across all economic sectors to stimulate growth and development.
• International investment in Peru increased significantly during the 1990s due to the country's progress toward economic, social, and political stability.
• Investment inflows slowed in 2000 as a result of government delays in privatization processes and rising political uncertainty.
• President Alejandro Toledo prioritized investment promotion during his administration to sustain and enhance foreign investment levels.

• Under former President Alberto Fujimori, Peru addressed critical issues such as terrorism, hyperinflation, and excessive government intervention in the economy, which previously hindered investment.
• Despite improvements, Peru's democratic institutions, particularly the judiciary, remain weak, posing challenges to governance and investment confidence.

• The Government of Peru implemented an economic stabilization and liberalization program that reduced trade barriers, removed restrictions on capital flows, and opened the economy to foreign investment.
• As a result of these reforms, Peru established one of the most open investment regimes globally.
• Between 1992 and 2001, Peru attracted nearly $17 billion in foreign direct investment, a substantial increase from negligible levels before 1991.
• The main sources of foreign direct investment during this period were Spain (32.35%), the United States (17.51%), Switzerland (6.99%), Chile (6.63%), and Mexico (5.53%).
• The legal framework governing foreign investment in Peru is based on the 1993 Constitution, the Private Investment Growth Law, and the Investment Promotion Law enacted in November 1996.

• Although Peru does not have a bilateral investment treaty with the United States, it signed a 1993 agreement with the Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC) regarding OPIC-financed loans, guarantees, and investments.

• Peru has committed to resolving investment disputes through arbitration under the International Center for the Settlement of Investment Disputes (ICSID), affiliated with the World Bank, or through other international or national arbitration tribunals.
• The sol is the official currency of Peru, with an exchange rate of 3.76 soles to the US dollar as of January 2025.
• The sol was introduced in 1991 after the Peruvian government abandoned the inti due to hyperinflation affecting the currency.
• Since its introduction, the sol has maintained the lowest inflation rate in Latin America.
• The sol replaced the inti at a conversion rate of 1 nuevo sol = 1,000,000 intis.
• The inti itself had replaced an earlier currency also called the sol, which was in use from 1863 to 1985 and had suffered from inflation.
• The name "sol" is derived from the Latin word "solidus" and is also the Spanish word for "sun," which was worshiped by the ancient Inca civilization as the god Inti.
• The sol currently has a low inflation rate of 2.5%.
• Since its introduction, the sol’s exchange rate with the US dollar has generally fluctuated between 2.80 and 3.30 soles per dollar.
• Among Latin American currencies, the sol is recognized as the most stable and reliable, being the least affected by declines in the value of the US dollar.
• During late 2007 and early 2008, the sol’s exchange rate dropped to 2.69 soles per US dollar, a level not seen since 1997.
• The exchange rate of the sol is determined daily by the Banco Central de Reserva del Perú (Central Reserve Bank of Peru).
• The sol is subdivided into 100 céntimos.
• The highest-denomination banknote currently in circulation is the 200 soles note.
• The lowest-denomination coin is the 5 céntimos coin, which is rarely used.

• Peru categorizes its population into five socio-economic classes labeled A through E, where Class A represents the rich, Class B the upper middle class, Class C the middle class, Class D the working class and low-income families, and Class E the marginalized poor.
• In 2018, Miguel Planas from the Ministry of Finance described these socio-economic segments as "crude" due to the complex societal structure in Peru.
• The complexity arises because certain classes generate income through illegal trade activities, which are not accounted for in the country's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• As a result of uncounted illegal income, some individuals or families are inaccurately classified as low income or marginalized poor, despite potentially having higher actual earnings.
• The unemployment rate in Greater Lima is recorded at 5.6%, indicating the proportion of the labor force without employment in this metropolitan area.
• In contrast, the unemployment rate for the rest of Peru, outside Greater Lima, is higher at 7%, reflecting regional disparities in employment opportunities.
• According to the fiscal year 2012–2013 report, the total number of workers employed in the public sector across Peru amounted to 1.45 million individuals.

• From 1994 through 1998, under President Alberto Fujimori's government, Peru experienced robust economic growth primarily driven by foreign direct investment, with nearly 46% of such investment linked to the country's privatization program.
• During Fujimori's administration, the government made significant investments in national infrastructure, establishing a strong foundation for the future development of the Peruvian economy.

• Between 1998 and 2001, Peru's economy stagnated due to multiple adverse factors including the century's strongest El Niño weather phenomenon, global financial turmoil, political instability, a stalled privatization program, increased government market intervention, and deteriorating terms of trade.

• Upon assuming office, President Alejandro Toledo implemented an economic recovery program characterized by largely orthodox policies and efforts to attract investment, including the resumption of the privatization program.
• Despite these measures, political uncertainty contributed to a minimal GDP growth rate of 0.2% in 2001.
• The Lima Stock Exchange general index experienced significant declines, falling by 34.5% in 2000 and by 0.2% in 2001.
• Inflation rates remained low during this period, registering 3.7% in 2000 and experiencing deflation of 0.1% in 2001.

• The government's overall budget deficit increased sharply to 3.2% of GDP in 1999 and 2000, driven by increased government salaries, election campaign expenditures in 2000, higher foreign debt service payments, and reduced tax revenues.
• By 2001, the government reduced the budget deficit to 2.5% of GDP and set a target to further reduce it to 1.9% of GDP in 2002.

• Economic stability contributed to a substantial reduction in underemployment, which dropped from an average of 74% during the late 1980s through 1994 to 43% in the 1995–96 period; however, underemployment rates began rising again between 1997 and 2002, exceeding half of the working population.
• The poverty rate in Peru remained at 54% in 2001, with 24% of the population living in extreme poverty.
• By 2005, the extreme poverty rate had decreased to 18%, and the overall poverty rate declined to 39%.
• As of 2010, approximately 30% of Peru's total population was classified as poor.
• Peru’s population of approximately 30 million positions it as a midsized state that benefits from the contemporary multi-polar world, allowing it to avoid dependence on a single major power patron.

• Peru’s strategic infrastructure includes expanding ports facilitating exports to China and a new superhighway connecting to Brazil, complemented by a free trade agreement with the United States, collectively enhancing its prospects for economic prosperity.
• Former President Alejandro Toledo expressed concerns that Peru’s future political stability may hinge on the government’s ability to achieve more equitable wealth distribution.
• Peru’s real GDP growth was 8.3% in 2007 and surged to 9.8% in 2008, marking the highest growth rate in Latin America and the world for that year.
• Inflation in Peru remained low at approximately 3%, while the budget surplus was projected to stay around 1% of GDP during this period.
• Private investment was expected to grow at an annual rate of 15%, with exports and imports anticipated to continue increasing.

• Unemployment and underemployment rates in Lima were 5.2% and 34%, respectively, with expectations of decline as the economy expanded; other cities such as Cajamarca, Ica, Cuzco, and Trujillo also began experiencing reductions in unemployment.
• Key sectors attracting domestic and foreign investment included tourism, agriculture, mining, petroleum and natural gas, power industries, and financial institutions.
• According to IMF and World Bank data, Peru’s GDP growth rates were: 8.9% in 2007, 9.7% in 2008, 0.9% in 2009, 8.6% in 2010, 6.0% in 2011, 6.3% in 2012, and 5.3% in 2013.
• Over the six-year period from 2007 to 2013, Peru’s GDP experienced a cumulative growth of 45.7%, equating to an average annual growth rate of 7.61%.
• The IMF forecasted that Peru’s economy would continue to grow at an average rate of 7% annually from 2013 to 2019.

• In fiscal year 2011, Peru’s economy surpassed Chile’s in size for the first time since 1991, making Peru the fifth largest economy in South America, with projections to become the fourth largest by 2018 by overtaking Venezuela.
• Private investment accounted for 25% of GDP in 2007 and remained stable through 2010.
• Inflation was controlled at an average rate of 2% annually, projected to continue at this level for the subsequent five years.
• Peru’s international debt was expected to decline from 35% of GDP in 2006 to 25% by 2010, and further reduce to 12% by 2015.

• The International Monetary Reserves of Peru’s National Reserve Bank, comprising assets in US dollars, euros, yen, gold, and other currencies, increased from US$27 billion at the end of 2007 to US$31 billion at the end of 2008.
• By the end of fiscal year 2013, Peru’s international reserves reached approximately US$73 billion, more than doubling the country’s total foreign debt of US$30 billion at that time.
• Peru’s exports grew at an annual rate of 25%, reaching US$28 billion at the end of 2007, US$30 billion at the end of 2010, and US$46 billion in fiscal year 2012.
• Investment in high technology sectors was rapidly increasing and was projected to constitute 10% of Peru’s GDP by 2010.
• Coca has a long history of cultivation in the Andes and has traditionally been an integral part of Peruvian life.
• The narcotic properties of coca were known only locally until 1786, when the botanist Lamarck included the leaf in his botanical encyclopedia.
• Following the arrival of the Spanish in Peru, coca cultivation increased significantly, and its use became more widespread throughout the region.
• Since 1543, coca has been internationally recognized for its trading value, with regulations imposed on it that have progressively increased the plant’s economic importance.
• The exchange of coca leaves between consumers in the Andean highlands and growers in the low-lying hills has been ongoing for at least the last millennium, reinforcing local economic relationships.
• Between 1884 and 1900, coca and cocaine gained popularity in the United States for medical purposes and mass consumption.
• From 1905 to 1922, anti-cocaine sentiments in the United States led to the criminalization of both coca and cocaine.
• It was not until the 1920s that United States diplomats began efforts to extend drug prohibitions on coca and cocaine at the international level.
• The Peruvian coca and cocaine industry has expanded significantly due to high demand for drugs from advanced industrial nations, creating a dependency on "coca-dollars" and US drug policy.
• Cocaine trafficking revenue supports local economies, contributes to inflation, and induces social changes such as cocaine smoking among indigenous Peruvians.
• In the Apurímac River region, a major coca-growing area, coca farming accounts for 48% of total net family income for peasants, highlighting its economic importance.

• For the past 50 years, the US government in collaboration with the United Nations has waged a war on drugs aimed at reducing drug use in America, with the US Drug Control Program emphasizing that eliminating illicit coca and opium cultivation is the best strategy to combat cocaine and heroin availability in the US.
• In 1995, with US cooperation, the Peruvian Government implemented the National Plan for the Prevention and Control of Drugs, resulting in a 70% reduction in coca leaf cultivation since that year.

• Despite the reduction in coca cultivation, advances in coca growing techniques and more efficient processing methods have allowed for increased cocaine yields, potentially offsetting the impact on overall cocaine production.
• The narcotics industry’s economic size in Peru is difficult to quantify but is estimated to range between $300 million and $600 million.
• Approximately 200,000 Peruvian households depend economically on the production, refining, or distribution of coca.
• Economists suggest that large inflows of dollars from the narcotics trade into the banking system contribute to the persistent depreciation of the US dollar relative to the Peruvian sol.
• The Central Bank of Peru conducts open market operations to prevent the sol from appreciating to levels that would make Peruvian exports prohibitively expensive.

• In response to interdiction efforts by the Peruvian Air Force in the mid-1990s, drug traffickers have diversified transportation methods, now using land, river routes, and aircraft to move cocaine paste and refined cocaine domestically and internationally.

• The Air Bridge Denial Program was suspended in April 2001 after a tragic incident where the Peruvian Air Force, with US DEA involvement, mistakenly shot down a civilian aircraft, killing two American citizens.

• Peru continues active counter-narcotics measures including arresting traffickers, seizing drugs and precursor chemicals, destroying coca processing labs, disabling clandestine airstrips, and prosecuting officials involved in narcotics-related corruption.

• The Peruvian Government, with limited support from the US Agency for International Development (USAID), implements alternative development programs in major coca-growing regions to encourage farmers to switch from coca cultivation.
• Initially focusing on eradication of coca seed beds, the government began eradicating mature coca plants in national parks and main coca valleys in 1998 and 1999.
• In 1999, the government eradicated over 150 km² of coca cultivation, but this figure declined to 65 km² in 2000, largely due to political instability.
• The government agency "Contradrogas," established in 1996, coordinates counter-narcotics efforts among various Peruvian government bodies.

• Alternative crops promoted as substitutes for coca are economically less lucrative; in 2004, annual income per hectare was $600 for coffee and $1000 for cocoa, compared to up to $7500 per hectare for coca.
• Peru is a key player in the global green economy due to its abundant mineral resources essential for sustainable technologies, including copper, lithium, silver, zinc, and rare earth elements.
• As of 2024, Peru is the world’s second-largest exporter of copper, silver, zinc, and lithium, minerals critical for advancing cleaner and more sustainable industrial technologies.

• In August 2024, Peru and the United States signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to enhance foreign direct investment (FDI) and foster shared technological innovation focused on responsible mineral extraction.

• Peru holds more than 6 tons of lithium reserves and manages 31 active copper projects with nearly US$40 billion in potential investments, underscoring its strategic importance in the global mineral supply chain.
• The 2024 Peru-US partnership signifies a new era for the Peruvian economy, positioning Peru as a reliable supplier of essential minerals for the US and supporting sustainable economic growth.
• The anti-coca policies implemented in Peru in 1995 have negatively impacted household economies, particularly for families reliant on coca farming.
• The eradication of coca crops has led to a reduction in household income, compelling many families to send their children to work.
• In Peruvian states where coca is cultivated, child labor increased by 18% in 1997 and further escalated to 40% by the year 2000.
• Alongside the rise in child labor, there was an increase in work hours and domestic responsibilities, with girls undertaking 28% more domestic work and boys performing 13% more domestic work.
• Since 1995, wage labor among adults has also increased, suggesting that children are compensating for the labor lost by working parents affected by eradication policies.
• The correlation between the rise in child labor and the enforcement of coca eradication policies indicates that children are filling labor gaps caused by the economic strain on their families.

• Despite these changes, child labor in coca production remains an ongoing issue in Peru, as documented in the 2013 U.S. Department of Labor report titled _Findings on the Worst Forms of Child Labor_.

• Additionally, the problem was highlighted in December 2014 in the Bureau of International Labor Affairs' publication, _List of Goods Produced by Child Labor or Forced Labor_, confirming the persistence of child labor in the sector.
• According to Transparency International's Corruption Perceptions Index, Peru ranks as the 101st least corrupt country in the world.
• The Peruvian organization "Ciudadanos al Dia" has initiated efforts to measure and compare transparency, costs, and efficiency across various government departments in Peru.
• "Ciudadanos al Dia" annually awards best practices in government transparency and efficiency, an initiative that has garnered widespread media attention.
• The recognition and media coverage from "Ciudadanos al Dia" have fostered competition among government agencies to improve their transparency and operational efficiency.
• A notable corruption case in Peru was the 2008 oil scandal, which triggered protests in major cities throughout the country.
• The 2008 oil scandal led to the resignation of the entire cabinet as a consequence of the public outcry and political pressure.
• Despite the scandal and cabinet resignation, a judge acquitted all officials involved in the 2008 oil scandal case in 2016.

• The main economic indicators for Peru from 1980 to 2021 are presented with IMF staff estimates for 2022 to 2027, including GDP in billion US$ PPP and nominal terms, GDP per capita in US$ PPP and nominal terms, real GDP growth rate, inflation rate, unemployment rate, and government debt as a percentage of GDP.

• In 1980, Peru's GDP was $53.9 billion (PPP) and $20.2 billion (nominal), with a GDP per capita of $3,111.3 (PPP) and $1,164.8 (nominal), a real GDP growth of 7.7%, inflation at 59.1%, unemployment at 7.3%, and government debt data not available.

• Throughout the 1980s, Peru experienced high inflation rates, peaking at 7,481.7% in 1990, with negative GDP growth rates in several years, including -9.3% in 1983 and -13.4% in 1989, while unemployment fluctuated between 4.2% and 9.0%.

• The 1990s saw gradual economic stabilization with inflation decreasing from hyperinflation levels to 3.5% by 1999, GDP growth recovering to positive rates such as 12.3% in 1994, and unemployment rates generally around 7-9%, with government debt data becoming available from 2000 at 44.9% of GDP.

• From 2000 to 2019, Peru's economy showed steady growth, with GDP increasing from $50.4 billion nominal in 2000 to $232.3 billion nominal in 2019, GDP per capita rising from $1,940.2 to $7,006.3 nominal, real GDP growth rates mostly positive (ranging from 1.1% to 9.1%), inflation rates generally below 5% (except 5.8% in 2008), unemployment rates between 6.6% and 9.4%, and government debt declining from 44.9% in 2000 to around 26.9% in 2019.

• The year 2020 marked a significant economic contraction due to external shocks, with GDP falling by 11.0%, GDP nominal value dropping to $205.8 billion, GDP per capita nominal decreasing to $6,145.0, unemployment rising sharply to 13.9%, inflation remaining low at 1.8%, and government debt increasing to 35.0% of GDP.

• Recovery began in 2021 with a 13.6% real GDP growth, GDP nominal value rebounding to $225.9 billion, GDP per capita nominal increasing to $6,678.9, inflation at 4.0%, unemployment decreasing to 10.9%, and government debt slightly rising to 36.4% of GDP.

• IMF estimates for 2022 to 2027 project continued economic growth with GDP rising from $239.3 billion nominal in 2022 to $307.4 billion nominal in 2027, GDP per capita nominal increasing from $7,004.8 to $8,560.9, real GDP growth rates stabilizing around 2.6% to 3.2%, inflation rates expected to decline from 7.5% in 2022 to 2.0% by 2027, unemployment rates improving from 7.6% to 7.0%, and government debt gradually decreasing from 34.8% to 34.3% of GDP.
• Peru's poverty rate data from 2004 to 2012 is noted but specific figures are not provided in this section.
• Household income or consumption distribution in 2000 showed the lowest 10% of the population holding 0.8% of income or consumption share, while the highest 10% held 37.5%.
• The inflation rate for consumer prices was 2.08% in 2010.
• Peru's government budget in 2014 estimated revenues at $57 billion and expenditures at $50 billion, including $3.8 billion in long-term capital expenditures as of 2010.
• Industrial production growth rate was estimated at 12% in 2013.
• Electricity production in 2013 was 175,500 GWh, with generation sources comprising 44.53% natural gas, 54.79% hydroelectric, 0% nuclear, and 0.68% other sources.
• Electricity consumption in 2013 was 133,000 GWh, with exports of 32,000 kWh mainly to Ecuador, and no electricity imports recorded.
• Peru's agricultural products include coffee, cotton, sugarcane, rice, wheat, potatoes, plantains, coca, poultry, beef, dairy products, wool, and fish.
• In 2013, Peru's total exports were valued at $73.5 billion f.o.b., consisting of $63.5 billion in goods and products and $10.5 billion in services.

• Major export commodities in 2013 included fish and fish products, copper, zinc, gold, molybdenum, iron, crude petroleum and byproducts, lead, coffee, asparagus, artichokes, paprika, sugar, cotton, textiles, chemicals, pharmaceuticals, manufactures, machinery, and services.

• Peru's main export partners in 2013 were Mainland China (20%), United States (15%), European Union (15%), Brazil (10%), Chile (10%), Japan (5%), Mexico (5%), United Kingdom (5%), Bolivia (5%), with the rest of Latin America and the rest of the world each accounting for 5%.

• Total imports in 2013 were $68 billion f.o.b., with key import commodities including machinery, transport equipment, foodstuffs, iron and steel, pharmaceuticals, electronics, petroleum, and chemicals.

• Peru's main import partners in 2013 were Mainland China (25%), United States (15%), European Union (15%), Brazil (10%), Japan (10%), Chile (5%), Colombia (5%), Mexico (5%), Ecuador (4%), Bolivia (1%), and the rest of the world (5%).

• According to the Ministry of Foreign Trade and Tourism, Peru pursued trade agreements to secure permanent, unlimited-in-time and coverage benefits for Peruvian exports in key markets, replacing temporary commercial preferences previously granted unilaterally by certain countries, which hindered long-term export-related investments by Peruvian exporters.

• Under the Economic Complementation Agreement framework, Peru has the Integration Agreement with the Andean Community of Nations, including Bolivia, Ecuador, and Colombia, which was signed and became effective in 1969.
• Peru signed ACE 50 with Cuba in October 2000, which came into effect in 2001 under the Economic Complementation Agreement.
• Peru signed ACE 58 with Mercosur in August 2003, and it became effective in November 2005, furthering economic integration under the Economic Complementation Agreement.
• Peru’s Free Trade Agreement (FTA) with the United States was signed in April 2006 and became effective in February 2009, marking a significant bilateral trade relationship.
• The FTA with Chile was signed in August 2006 and came into force in March 2009, enhancing trade ties between the two countries.
• Peru signed the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPFTA) with Canada in May 2008, which became effective in August 2009.
• An FTA with Singapore was also signed in May 2008 and became effective in August 2009, expanding Peru’s trade network in Asia.
• The FTA with China was signed in April 2009 and entered into force in March 2010, representing a major trade agreement with a global economic power.
• Peru’s FTA with South Korea was signed in March 2011 and became effective in August 2011, strengthening economic ties with East Asia.
• A partial FTA with Thailand was finalized with the last protocol signed in November 2010 and became effective in December 2011, indicating partial trade liberalization.
• The FTA with Mexico was signed in April 2011 and came into effect in February 2012, enhancing regional trade integration.
• Peru signed an FTA with Japan in May 2011, which became effective in March 2012, further linking Peru to the Asia-Pacific region.
• The FTA with Panama was signed in May 2011 and became effective in May 2012, expanding trade relations in Central America.

• Peru signed an FTA with the European Free Trade Association (EFTA) countries—Switzerland, Liechtenstein, Iceland, and Norway—in July 2010; Switzerland and Liechtenstein’s agreements became effective in July 2011, Iceland’s in October 2011, and Norway’s in July 2012.
• The FTA with the European Union was signed in April 2011 and became effective in February 2013, marking a major trade agreement with a large economic bloc.
• Peru’s FTA with Costa Rica was signed in May 2011 and became effective in June 2013, strengthening trade ties within Central America.
• A partial FTA with Venezuela was signed in January 2012 and became effective in August 2013, indicating limited trade liberalization.
• Peru signed an FTA with the Pacific Alliance in February 2014, which became effective in May 2016, promoting regional economic integration among member countries.
• The FTA with Honduras was signed in May 2015 and became effective in January 2017, further expanding Peru’s trade agreements in Central America.

• Peru concluded FTAs that are signed but not yet in force with Guatemala (signed December 2011), Brazil (signed April 2016), Australia (signed February 2018), and the Comprehensive and Progressive Agreement for Trans-Pacific Partnership (CPTPP) (signed March 2018).
• Peru is currently negotiating Free Trade Agreements with El Salvador, India, and Turkey, indicating ongoing efforts to expand its trade network globally.

sections.section_name: Peru – United States Trade Promotion Agreement
openai_summarised_points: • The United States – Peru Trade Promotion Agreement (Spanish: Tratado de Libre Comercio Perú – Estados Unidos) is a bilateral free trade agreement aimed at eliminating obstacles to trade, consolidating access to goods and services, and fostering private investment between the United States and Peru.
• Beyond commercial issues, the agreement incorporates economic, institutional, intellectual property, labor, and environmental policies among other areas.

• The agreement was signed on 12 April 2006; ratified by the Peruvian Congress on 28 June 2006; ratified by the U.S. House of Representatives on 2 November 2007; ratified by the U.S. Senate on 4 December 2007; and implemented on 1 February 2009.

• Peru’s objectives for the agreement include consolidating and extending trade preferences under the Andean Trade Promotion and Drug Eradication Act (ATPDEA), attracting foreign investment, generating employment, enhancing the country's competitiveness within the region, increasing workers’ income, curbing poverty levels, and creating and exporting sugar cane ethanol.
• The United States aims to improve access to goods and services, strengthen its investments, promote security and democracy, and fight against drug trafficking through the agreement.

• The agreement faced criticism in Peru; it was championed by President Alejandro Toledo and supported to varying degrees by former President Alan García and presidential candidates Lourdes Flores and Valentín Paniagua.

• Ollanta Humala, leader of the Union for Peru party, was the most vocal critic of the agreement; his party won 45 of 120 seats in the 2006 Congress, the largest share by a single party, which sparked debate on the agreement’s ratification before the new legislature was sworn in.
• Some Congressmen-elect forcibly entered Congress to interrupt the debate and attempt to stop the ratification of the agreement.

• A controversial element of the agreement concerns land resources; Laura Carlsen of the Center for International Policy, also a contributor to Foreign Policy in Focus, noted that indigenous organizations warn the ruling effectively opens up 45 million hectares to foreign investment and exploitation by timber, oil, and mining industries.

• Most criticism focused on the agreement’s potential negative impact on Peru’s agricultural sector, as Peruvian farmers growing crops similar to those subsidized by the U.S. faced a competitive disadvantage due to inadequate tools, technology, and techniques, limiting their ability to produce exportable crops at competitive prices.

• In response to agricultural sector concerns, Peruvian lawmakers established a Compensation Fund allocating $34 million per year for five years to support cotton, maize/corn, and wheat producers in adjusting to new competitive pressures.
• Alejandro Toledo is characterized as a market-oriented politician who continued to globalize Peru’s economy and was rumored to be preparing for another presidential run.
• Toledo emphasized that the Peruvian economic miracle would stall unless the poorest citizens are better educated, better paid, housed, and fed.
